This year, St. George's actual feast day (23rd April) for the Orthodox fell on the Saturday of Holy Week. So his feast is transferred to today, the Monday of Bright Week.

Saint George is such an immensely popular Saint in the Orthodox Church, we couldn't possibly celebrate his bright feast during Holy Week or Lent. If this happens, the feast is transferred to the Monday of Pascha (Easter Week).

Today has been an eye-opener! 
When you work with some of the most wonderful, supportive, understanding and helpful school admin ever, and then you come across a couple of dissembling,  twisting anonymous "SBM" twitter trolls. Shocking! I hope they are not like that in real life.

@LancsSbm @accidentalSBM @thosethatcan p.s. You know nothing about my values. Christian or not. Common decency says you don't manufacture division between classroom based staff and others.

@LancsSbm @accidentalSBM @thosethatcan In fact, the very tweet that you reply to says admin and classroom staff get along. 
I have asked for the "them and us" to stop. It seems the misrepresentation has worked and pile on continues.

@LancsSbm @accidentalSBM @thosethatcan Your colleague created the division by twisting the original tweet by Tom Rogers and subsequently misrepresenting my replies. 
Tom was saying how those outside school don't appreciate how busy teachers get. She read office as school office. Maybe a word with literacy coordinator.

@LancsSbm @accidentalSBM @thosethatcan I have been misrepresented. 
I didn't immediately recognise the acronym SBM. I am thick with cold. 
I know what a SBM, bursar, finance manager or whatever title schools give does. I know very well.  I have repeatedly said we need to work together. 
1/2

@The_Data_Adonis @accidentalSBM @thosethatcan I completely agree.

@Jackofatrade @accidentalSBM You are right. Every role has its difficulties ; A & E certainly has.

A comparison was made with office workers and teachers. Teaching is a profession bound by bells, and unpaid work outside hours.

A guy says teachers (understood as school workers)  don't get to pee or drink tea like your standard office job and this entitled numpty reads it as an attack on her school role. It's not about you!
@MalCPD @accidentalSBM @RogersHistory @thosethatcan That's what I thought. Not just me then! Blimey!

@accidentalSBM First, I don't think that was aimed at school staff. Second, office staff anywhere are not usually bound by a bell. The same is not true of factory workers, warehouse staff etc., who often are limited. Teachers too!

@tankhead666 @vivienmiss @mrsluc @DeborahMeaden Of course, these virtue signalling xenophobes take in all our homeless from the street and put them up themselves. How many homeless veterans did they take in? 
Hypocrites.

@maw6578 Why would you go to somewhere that you cannot speak the language and have no-one to support you, when you could join relatives and be safe and supported. Most civilised nations allow that, we don't!

@maw6578 Not what she said.

@accidentalSBM @thosethatcan It often stems from a basic failure to understand that teachers teach. They are in a classroom for set hours in the day. They run clubs, ex interventions, detentions, mark books. 
In some places there seems to be an expectation to be replying to emails all day.

@accidentalSBM @thosethatcan The attitude cones across as "entitled". "What about the rest of us!" as though teacher tiredness doesn't count. 
Without giving away details, there are myriad examples. Some SBM are SLT/HR and abuse that position. Speaking as a former union branch president and witnessed this.

@accidentalSBM You brought the SBM in! It's not a competition, we work together. Maybe in your workplace classroom staff do get a break and a chance to  eat/pee. It's sadly not the norm. No-one said you aren't busy! It's not them vs us.

Both have a theoretical equinox. The Orthodox Church uses ancient C4th calculation cycles from Alexandria based on the Julian calendar. Rome uses a modernist (ğŸ˜‰) computus innovation of the 16th Century  and  Gregorian Calendar.

My Dad's carers spent a good few minutes trying to find the Ostrich eggs that he wanted for breakfast in the fridge. 
"We can't see them" they say to the nearly 90 year old. "You can't miss them, they're huge!" 
Then he asks if they've written up the notes with the date.
